# INTRODUCTION

States' attempts to regulate the battlefield behavior of their own and other states' belligerents are not new. Yet only in recent modernity have states focused on a set of *jus in bello* rules, allowing them to crystallize into a complex framework of inter-dependent textual and customary law. As currently understood, the rules of international humanitarian law (IHL), have two main problems.

One problem is theoretical. IHL rules forge a balance between deontological humanitarian concerns on one hand, and consequentialist military-advantage concerns on the other hand. Yet the literature provides inadequate theoretical foundations for the balances these rules make at a structural level. IHL theories can be described as fal-

ling into two parallel approaches. On one hand, the standard account holds that humanitarian law “impose[s] some limits, however ineffective, to a complete reversion to anarchy by the establishment of minimum standards on the conduct of war.”¹ These scholars’ methodology, however, is ad hoc and unsatisfying. On the other hand, the rationalist or economic account posits that such laws—and state practice—are merely epiphenomenal of states’ interests; on this account the rules are “behavioral regularities rather than constraints on self-interested behavior.”² The economic account provides methodological rigor but discounts the deontological constraints that inhere in formal doctrine and state practice.

The second problem is substantive. As I show below, IHL rules balance a variety of concerns, including moral constraints against killing noncombatants, attempts to minimize battlefield uncertainty, and states’ preferences for rules and tactics that reduce the costs of executing wars. In an age where technological advancements are rapidly changing the menu of tactical options from which states may choose in carrying out armed conflict, IHL rules will need to be reconsidered to determine whether they fit the emerging and operational opportunities and threats posed by cyberwarfare.

In this paper, I address each of these problems.

Regarding the first problem, I explain the standard and rationalist (economic) accounts of IHL rules, then explain how these accounts cannot alone account for the diversity of rules and principles observed in the formal doctrine and in state practice. I then seek a synthesis of the two strands of IHL scholarship, arguing that states’ revealed preference for norms fleshing out those “minimum standards” can not be brushed aside as mere “behavioral regularities.” To be sure, many of these minimum standards are the result of purely instrumental coordination, since all belligerents are better off with full compliance under conditions of transparency and effective enforcement. But recognizing that states sometimes act for non-instrumental reasons supplements rather than falsifies claims that states act rationally under other circumstances. By relying on psychological theories of moral cognition, which explain how people justify their decisions about whether to follow one or another mutually inconsistent behavioral prescriptions, it is possible to talk about instrumental and non-instrumental rationales in the same breath.³

Even bracketing this psychological approach, which is kindred with recent advances in behavioral law and economics, scholars have also developed an economic framework for analyzing non-instrumental constraints on instrumental logic. In a recent book, Eyal Zamir and Barak Medina bridge the gap between consequentialist and deontological moral theories—which tracks a similar gap between instrumental and non-instrumental logic—by imposing threshold conditions on social welfare functions.⁴ As I explain in greater detail in Part II, by using Zamir and Medina’s deontologically constrained cost-benefit analysis (“constrained CBA”) approach, scholars are better able to explain and understand complex bodies of law that are the product of instrumental and non-instrumental concerns alike.⁵

In the second half of the paper, I apply the constrained CBA approach to examine the emerging substantive problem of cyberwar. I shift focus from the theoretical to the substantive by showing how the concerns identified in the first part of the paper can and should influence institutional design considerations, especially under conditions of uncertainty about future battlefield situations. I aim to explore how states might seek to change those rules in light of anticipated (and even unknown) changes in battlefield technology.

## I. MODELING THE LAWS OF WAR

### A. Standard Account

Over centuries, social practices and wars have had constitutive effects on each other. The emergence of the modern nation-state—relatively recent in human history—was to some extent itself a measure to reduce the violence endemic to pre-social anarchy. States found untrammeled violence endemic in the anarchy of the battlefield, too, and micro-scale civilizing processes occurred there through the constitutive interplay of state practice and emerging norms of warfare.⁶

Enlightened states in an enlightened era recognized the importance of limiting war's primary effects to military targets. Early multilateral statements to this effect emphasized that “the progress of civilization should have the effect of alleviating as much as possible the calamities of war,” accomplished by states placing noncombatants off-limits and seeking only to “weaken the military forces of the enemy.”¹¹ The Lieber Code made clear that “military necessity does not admit of cruelty—that is, the infliction of suffering for the sake of suffering or for revenge.”¹²

They appear in the core humanitarian law principles of distinction, military necessity, and proportionality, insofar as those rules seek to protect noncombatants against accidental or unnecessary exposure to the harms inherent to war. Many of these rules admit no balancing test and permit no exception; they deal in absolutes. These intransgressible principles¹⁷ have the feel of deontological constraints against war's means. I say they have this "feel" because, as Eric Posner correctly notes, "it is hard to find a detailed defense" of these intransgressible principles on deontological grounds.¹⁸ The details of the defense appear piecemeal from a formalist reading of the doctrine and commentary, as well as from a functionalist reading of what states seek to accomplish in setting limits on the means of war. The position that military necessity permits means of effectively bringing about "the complete submission of the enemy" while minimizing the costs of war is not absolute; the set of possible means is limited by the requirement that such means be consistent with IHL.¹⁹ Indeed, Additional Protocol I to the Geneva Conventions exhorts that "the right of the Parties to [an international armed] conflict to choose methods or means of warfare is not unlimited."²⁰ To that end, the few theorists who have addressed deontological ethics during wartime (like Michael Walzer) have emphasized the rights-centric nature of IHL rules, especially with regard to noncombatants.²¹ Even accepting that sometimes states will resort to war and that sometimes combatants will be killed (for this is their purpose), "no one else is made to be killed."²²

Given such constraints, it does not make much sense to describe or try to understand these rules solely in the language of consequentialism. Despite the seeming inconsistency between protections for combatants on one hand, and on the other hand the prosecution of an armed conflict that puts those combatants at risk of capture, injury, or death, IHL rules can also be justified on pragmatic grounds. States might agree ex ante that certain unduly harsh battlefield practices—such as no-quarter rules, or norms permitting the use of weapons that inflict unnecessary suffering—are particularly undesirable because they destroy morale among one's own troops notwithstanding the expected military advantage to be gained from their use.²⁹ States might also agree that targeting civilian populations through indiscriminate urban carpet-bombing campaigns, perhaps in an attempt to undercut civilian resolve and popular support for the war, is undesirable because it emboldens and entrenches the enemy.³⁰

These consequentialist rationales for IHL rules would differ in kind from the deontological (humanitarian) rationales for the same rules, but both kinds of rationales would cut in the same way. In other cases the rationales cut in different directions, sometimes in dispositive ways: IHL has rules in which consequentialist logic governs, and rules in which deontological logic governs. Consider one scholar's observation that

“the law of war allows ... the killing and wounding of innocent human beings not directly participating in an armed conflict, such as civilian victims of lawful collateral damage. As long as rules of the game are observed, it is permissible [in armed conflict] to cause suffering, deprivation of freedom, and death.”³¹

The “rules of the game” are sometimes absolute and nonderogable, as in the norms against torturing, summarily executing, or enslaving prisoners of war. According to the Nuremberg Tribunal’s judgment in the Hostage case, with regard to such rules “[m]ilitary necessity or expediency do not justify a violation.”³² Yet IHL plainly recognizes other circumstances in which military necessity is properly balanced against other interests. Consider how military necessity permits combatants to kill innocent noncombatants if proportionality threshold constraints are met.³³

Under the standard account, therefore, IHL rules are designed to serve not only humanitarian but also pragmatic interests. The perspective from which commentators and practitioners approach the problem of armed conflict is likely to manifest as a thumb on the scale in favor of one or the other interest.³⁴ Such differences in perspective are also likely to cause disagreements about the content of specific contentious rules. In light of such disagreements, it is remarkable that commentators and practitioners generally agree that international humanitarian law encompasses both humanitarian and pragmatic interests.³⁵

## B. Rationalist Account

The standard account can be contrasted with what is best described as the economic or rationalist account of IHL. Despite the substantial attention rationalist scholars have paid to diverse areas of international law, they have paid surprisingly little attention to the rules governing armed conflict. The rationalist turn in international law scholarship assumes states are egoistic unitary actors that maximize their self-interest.³⁷ Put simply, states are likely to violate international law where the costs of compliance outweigh the benefits. It is an open and closely contested question whether (or to what extent) rationalist accounts are better able to explain doctrine and state practice than other international-law perspectives (such as legal process, liberal, or constructivist theories). In this paper I accept the methodological framework of rationalist approaches in attempting a synthesis between economic and standard accounts of IHL. But accepting that states sometimes act consistent with rationalist predictions (following the logic of consequences) is not to deny that states sometimes act inconsistent with those predictions (following the logic of appropriateness). Even if rationalist explanations are sometimes underinclusive, other times the explanations are robust and show good fit with state practice.

Rationality assumptions undercut whatever force moral concerns may have, for rules are designed as instrumental means of serving states' strategic, material, and other interests. In other words, scholars within the rationalist tradition define the goals in terms of the interests that given rules serve, and costs and benefits that accrue from compliance with those rules. They emphasize the role that reciprocity plays in ensuring compliance, since rational states will not bear the costs of complying with the laws of war if they do not gain the benefits because the enemy is not complying.³⁸ On this account, IHL rules developed first because states were rationally interested in ensuring that their noncombatant citizens were not targeted and that their combatant soldiers were not treated inhumanely: "The concern for others was merely the reciprocal price to pay."³⁹

The reciprocity thesis has a strong pedigree in the history of international law. States' obligations under bilateral and multilateral treaties, and under certain rules of customary international law, turn in part on whether other parties (or states recognizing the custom) are holding up their end of the bargain.⁴⁰ Reciprocity norms also existed in strong form during the early periods of humanitarian law reform, although it is an open question whether state practice recognizes those norms as viable today.⁴¹ Either way, scholars continue to defend the reciprocity thesis today. As Eric Posner explains,

“states can implicitly agree on joint limits on the use of force as long as the limits make both states better off, each state can credibly threaten to retaliate against the other state for violating the limits, and each state cares enough about the future. The strategic problem is similar to the prisoner’s dilemma, and the solution is the same: mutual threats of retaliation.”⁴²

The reciprocity thesis thus provides an appealingly parsimonious, if otherwise imperfect, view of first-order IHL rules—at least when stated at a very abstract level of generality.⁴³ The parsimony of simple models makes them useful, if blunt, tools for understanding and explaining what “states” do. When states are taking simple interests into account, with no exogenous moral constraints (or when such constraints have been assumed away for methodological or other reasons), state practice sometimes resembles an iterated prisoner’s dilemma or some similar game. ## II. UPDATING THE ECONOMIC MODEL

## A. Constrained Cost-Benefit Analysis

The standard and rationalist accounts of IHL rules have their respective virtues. On one hand, the standard account shows good fit with state practice and doctrine, recognizing that deontological and consequentialist considerations have exerted real influence in the institutional evolution and substantive content of IHL rules. On the other hand, compared to the standard account, rationalist accounts generally provide superior methodological rigor. Yet such accounts have paid surprisingly little attention to the structure and content of IHL rules, and their focus on reciprocity is underinclusive.

It is possible to bridge the gap between the rationalist and standard accounts, taking advantage of the methodological advantages of the former and the substantive accuracy of the latter. Eyal Zamir and Barak Medina have proposed a new technique for incorporating threshold conditions from deontological reasoning into consequentialist analysis.⁴⁹ In the remainder of this paper, I employ their constrained CBA technique as a lens through which to analyze the interplay between humanitarian and pragmatic considerations in the design of IHL rules. In this draft I only briefly explain their approach before turning to a discussion of substantive IHL rules and the rules' implications under conditions of technological change and the emergence of cyberwarfare. I do so for space reasons, and in so doing I assume the reader at this preliminary stage is familiar with Zamir and Medina's thesis.

Constrained CBA is a tool that recognizes the methodological advantages that economic analysis provides. It also recognizes the risk that pure consequentialist analysis, and pure deontological analysis, can lead to normative outcomes that many find morally repugnant.⁵⁰ It employs threshold deontology, a middle-ground framework for ana-

States facing an international conflict have a menu of options to choose from. For our purposes the two important options are bargaining and going to war. Under the traditional rationalist explanations, states will choose war when the net gains expected from doing so outweigh the net gains expected from continued bargaining.59 Should a state choose war, it will expend resources—war capital—in the run-up and execution of war. In the usual case, expenditures will come from the state treasury and will be spread across the population; by preparing, maintaining, and deploying defensive and offensive capabilities, states provide classic public goods.60 These goods are often very bad, however: war is a wasteful and inefficient use of resources.61

# A. Technology in the Laws of War

Parties to an armed conflict rarely experience technological parity with one another. Some armed conflicts occur because parties attempt to achieve technological parity. A state may learn that an adversary has developed new means of warfare that are more destructive or more efficient than previous means. In light of uncertainty about the adversary's intentions—whether purely defensive or also offensive—a rational state will seek to close the technological gap. This creates an unraveling or spiraling effect known as the security dilemma, in which both parties' attempts to close the gap make all worse off.76 To the extent that security dilemmas are a function of asymmetrical endowments of new technologies between potential adversaries, states may recognize that they will be jointly better off if they can ban or limit the use of such technologies.

These joint gains come in two types. First, there are classical gains to be had from limiting wasteful expenditure on arms races, as well as from reducing the risk of costs associated with damage—in particular, both direct military damage and collateral noncombatant damage. Second, there are gains to be had from reducing the uncertainty inherent to new technologies. This uncertainty includes not only the amount of suffering inflicted on combatants relative to the military advantage gained, but also the magnitude or even threshold presence of damage inflicted on noncombatants and noncombatant objects. Recall from earlier that uncertainty increases the risk that threshold constraints may be violated. All else equal, norm entrepreneurs are likely to advocate for, and states are likely to adopt, rules that reduce the risk of inadvertently violating a threshold constraint.

Such concerns have driven states to adopt these rules. In practice, however, they have had limited success in doing so. States' attempts to regulate the battlefield behavior of their own and other states' belligerents are not new. Yet only in recent modernity have states focused on a set of *jus in bello* rules, allowing them to crystallize into a complex framework of inter-dependent textual and customary law. As currently understood, the rules of international humanitarian law (IHL), have two main problems.
One problem is theoretical. IHL rules forge a balance between deontological humanitarian concerns on one hand, and consequentialist military-advantage concerns on the other hand. The rationalist turn in international law scholarship assumes states are egoistic unitary actors that maximize their self-interest.³⁷ Put simply, states are likely to violate international law where the costs of compliance outweigh the benefits. It is an open and closely contested question whether (or to what extent) rationalist accounts are better able to explain doctrine and state practice than other international-law perspectives (such as legal process, liberal, or constructivist theories). In this paper I accept the methodological framework of rationalist approaches in attempting a synthesis between economic and standard accounts of IHL. But accepting that states sometimes act consistent with rationalist predictions (following the logic of consequences) is not to deny that states sometimes act inconsistent with those predictions (following the logic of appropriateness). Even if rationalist explanations are sometimes underinclusive, other times the explanations are robust and show good fit with state practice.
Rationality assumptions undercut whatever force moral concerns may have, for rules are designed as instrumental means of serving states' strategic, material, and other interests. ## II. UPDATING THE ECONOMIC MODEL
## A. Constrained Cost-Benefit Analysis
The standard and rationalist accounts of IHL rules have their respective virtues. On one hand, the standard account shows good fit with state practice and doctrine, recognizing that deontological and consequentialist considerations have exerted real influence in the institutional evolution and substantive content of IHL rules. On the other hand, compared to the standard account, rationalist accounts generally provide superior methodological rigor. Yet such accounts have paid surprisingly little attention to the structure and content of IHL rules, and their focus on reciprocity is underinclusive.
It is possible to bridge the gap between the rationalist and standard accounts, taking advantage of the methodological advantages of the former and the substantive accuracy of the latter. Eyal Zamir and Barak Medina have proposed a new technique for incorporating threshold conditions from deontological reasoning into consequentialist analysis.⁴⁹ In the remainder of this paper, I employ their constrained CBA technique as a lens through which to analyze the interplay between humanitarian and pragmatic considerations in the design of IHL rules. In this draft I only briefly explain their approach before turning to a discussion of substantive IHL rules and the rules' implications under conditions of technological change and the emergence of cyberwarfare. I do so for space reasons, and in so doing I assume the reader at this preliminary stage is familiar with Zamir and Medina's thesis.
Constrained CBA is a tool that recognizes the methodological advantages that economic analysis provides. It also recognizes the risk that pure consequentialist analysis, and pure deontological analysis, can lead to normative outcomes that many find morally repugnant.⁵⁰ It employs threshold deontology, a middle-ground framework for ana-

States facing an international conflict have a menu of options to choose from. For our purposes the two important options are bargaining and going to war. Under the traditional rationalist explanations, states will choose war when the net gains expected from doing so outweigh the net gains expected from continued bargaining.59 Should a state choose war, it will expend resources—war capital—in the run-up and execution of war. In the usual case, expenditures will come from the state treasury and will be spread across the population; by preparing, maintaining, and deploying defensive and offensive capabilities, states provide classic public goods.60 These goods are often very bad, however: war is a wasteful and inefficient use of resources.61
When rational states choose to go to war, they will also choose strategies and tactics that reduce the costs of doing so. Expenditures on the war effort will include not just fixed costs of procuring, supplying, and maintaining durable military hardware, but also the costs of maintaining the military bureaucracy, recruiting and retaining soldiers, and purchasing consumable goods such as butter for the mess hall or bombs for the airplanes. Soldiers can also be understood as consumable goods—at least as a historical matter. Technological and other structural changes in warfare have not only made the soldier less fungible, but also reduced the military necessity for treating the soldier as wholly consumable.62
Cost reduction strategies may manifest on the front end—constraining states' ability to make expenditures for those goods—as a consequence of political pressure. This is especially likely to be true where the decision to go to war has non-neutral distributive consequence.

# A. Technology in the Laws of War
Parties to an armed conflict rarely experience technological parity with one another. Some armed conflicts occur because parties attempt to achieve technological parity. A state may learn that an adversary has developed new means of warfare that are more destructive or more efficient than previous means. In light of uncertainty about the adversary's intentions—whether purely defensive or also offensive—a rational state will seek to close the technological gap. This creates an unraveling or spiraling effect known as the security dilemma, in which both parties' attempts to close the gap make all worse off.76 To the extent that security dilemmas are a function of asymmetrical endowments of new technologies between potential adversaries, states may recognize that they will be jointly better off if they can ban or limit the use of such technologies.
These joint gains come in two types. First, there are classical gains to be had from limiting wasteful expenditure on arms races, as well as from reducing the risk of costs associated with damage—in particular, both direct military damage and collateral noncombatant damage. Second, there are gains to be had from reducing the uncertainty inherent to new technologies. This uncertainty includes not only the amount of suffering inflicted on combatants relative to the military advantage gained, but also the magnitude or even threshold presence of damage inflicted on noncombatants and noncombatant objects. Recall from earlier that uncertainty increases the risk that threshold constraints may be violated. All else equal, norm entrepreneurs are likely to advocate for, and states are likely to adopt, rules that reduce the risk of inadvertently violating a threshold constraint.
Such concerns have driven states to adopt these rules. In practice, however, they have had limited success in doing so. # INTRODUCTION
States' attempts to regulate the battlefield behavior of their own and other states' belligerents are not new. Yet only in recent modernity have states focused on a set of *jus in bello* rules, allowing them to crystallize into a complex framework of inter-dependent textual and customary law. As currently understood, the rules of international humanitarian law (IHL), have two main problems.
One problem is theoretical. IHL rules forge a balance between deontological humanitarian concerns on one hand, and consequentialist military-advantage concerns on the other hand. Yet the literature provides inadequate theoretical foundations for the balances these rules make at a structural level. IHL theories can be described as fal-

On the other hand, the rationalist or economic account posits that such laws—and state practice—are merely epiphenomenal of states’ interests; on this account the rules are “behavioral regularities rather than constraints on self-interested behavior.” The economic account provides methodological rigor but discounts the deontological constraints that inhere in formal doctrine and state practice.

The rationalist turn in international law scholarship assumes states are egoistic unitary actors that maximize their self-interest. Put simply, states are likely to violate international law where the costs of compliance outweigh the benefits. ## II. UPDATING THE ECONOMIC MODEL
## A. Constrained Cost-Benefit Analysis
The standard and rationalist accounts of IHL rules have their respective virtues. On one hand, the standard account shows good fit with state practice and doctrine, recognizing that deontological and consequentialist considerations have exerted real influence in the institutional evolution and substantive content of IHL rules. On the other hand, compared to the standard account, rationalist accounts generally provide superior methodological rigor. Yet such accounts have paid surprisingly little attention to the structure and content of IHL rules, and their focus on reciprocity is underinclusive.

States facing an international conflict have a menu of options to choose from. For our purposes the two important options are bargaining and going to war. Under the traditional rationalist explanations, states will choose war when the net gains expected from doing so outweigh the net gains expected from continued bargaining.59 Should a state choose war, it will expend resources—war capital—in the run-up and execution of war. In the usual case, expenditures will come from the state treasury and will be spread across the population; by preparing, maintaining, and deploying defensive and offensive capabilities, states provide classic public goods.60 These goods are often very bad, however: war is a wasteful and inefficient use of resources.61
When rational states choose to go to war, they will also choose strategies and tactics that reduce the costs of doing so. Expenditures on the war effort will include not just fixed costs of procuring, supplying, and maintaining durable military hardware, but also the costs of maintaining the military bureaucracy, recruiting and retaining soldiers, and purchasing consumable goods such as butter for the mess hall or bombs for the airplanes. Soldiers can also be understood as consumable goods—at least as a historical matter. Technological and other structural changes in warfare have not only made the soldier less fungible, but also reduced the military necessity for treating the soldier as wholly consumable.62
Cost reduction strategies may manifest on the front end—constraining states' ability to make expenditures for those goods—as a consequence of political pressure. This is especially likely to be true where the decision to go to war has non-neutral distributive consequence.

# INTRODUCTION
States' attempts to regulate the battlefield behavior of their own and other states' belligerents are not new. Yet only in recent modernity have states focused on a set of *jus in bello* rules, allowing them to crystallize into a complex framework of inter-dependent textual and customary law. As currently understood, the rules of international humanitarian law (IHL), have two main problems.
One problem is theoretical. IHL rules forge a balance between deontological humanitarian concerns on one hand, and consequentialist military-advantage concerns on the other hand. Yet the literature provides inadequate theoretical foundations for the balances these rules make at a structural level. IHL theories can be described as fal-

On one hand, the standard account holds that humanitarian law “impose[s] some limits, however ineffective, to a complete reversion to anarchy by the establishment of minimum standards on the conduct of war.” These scholars’ methodology, however, is ad hoc and unsatisfying. On the other hand, the rationalist or economic account posits that such laws—and state practice—are merely epiphenomenal of states’ interests; on this account the rules are “behavioral regularities rather than constraints on self-interested behavior.” The economic account provides methodological rigor but discounts the deontological constraints that inhere in formal doctrine and state practice.
The second problem is substantive. As I show below, IHL rules balance a variety of concerns, including moral constraints against killing noncombatants, attempts to minimize battlefield uncertainty, and states’ preferences for rules and tactics that reduce the costs of executing wars. In an age where technological advancements are rapidly changing the menu of tactical options from which states may choose in carrying out armed conflict, IHL rules will need to be reconsidered to determine whether they fit the emerging and operational opportunities and threats posed by cyberwarfare.
In this paper, I address each of these problems.

The rationalist turn in international law scholarship assumes states are egoistic unitary actors that maximize their self-interest. Put simply, states are likely to violate international law where the costs of compliance outweigh the benefits. The standard and rationalist accounts of IHL rules have their respective virtues. On one hand, the standard account shows good fit with state practice and doctrine, recognizing that deontological and consequentialist considerations have exerted real influence in the institutional evolution and substantive content of IHL rules. On the other hand, compared to the standard account, rationalist accounts generally provide superior methodological rigor. Yet such accounts have paid surprisingly little attention to the structure and content of IHL rules, and their focus on reciprocity is underinclusive.

States facing an international conflict have a menu of options to choose from. For our purposes the two important options are bargaining and going to war. Parties to an armed conflict rarely experience technological parity with one another. Some armed conflicts occur because parties attempt to achieve technological parity. A state may learn that an adversary has developed new means of warfare that are more destructive or more efficient than previous means. In light of uncertainty about the adversary's intentions—whether purely defensive or also offensive—a rational state will seek to close the technological gap. This creates an unraveling or spiraling effect known as the security dilemma, in which both parties' attempts to close the gap make all worse off.76 To the extent that security dilemmas are a function of asymmetrical endowments of new technologies between potential adversaries, states may recognize that they will be jointly better off if they can ban or limit the use of such technologies.
These joint gains come in two types. First, there are classical gains to be had from limiting wasteful expenditure on arms races, as well as from reducing the risk of costs associated with damage—in particular, both direct military damage and collateral noncombatant damage. Second, there are gains to be had from reducing the uncertainty inherent to new technologies. This uncertainty includes not only the amount of suffering inflicted on combatants relative to the military advantage gained, but also the magnitude or even threshold presence of damage inflicted on noncombatants and noncombatant objects. Recall from earlier that uncertainty increases the risk that threshold constraints may be violated. All else equal, norm entrepreneurs are likely to advocate for, and states are likely to adopt, rules that reduce the risk of inadvertently violating a threshold constraint.

Similarly, the civilian who works at a research university or is otherwise a contractor seeking to develop pure technical means of penetrating networks might be “participating” in cyberwar in an abstract, attenuated sense, but the causal proximity will continue to be insufficient to cause the contractor to lose protection.
Optimal cyberwarfare rules will thus continue to track the current rules that govern direct participation in hostilities in kinetic attacks. The only serious difference between optimal cyberwar rules and status quo rules involves the responses states can make to civilians who directly participate in cyber attacks. Even if civilians might be targeted during the time their computer systems were participating in distributed denial of service attacks, or during the time that their computer continued to host a virus or worm, the scope of “targeting” would have to be limited. Rules about direct participation are special cases of the default rule that there are threshold constraints against killing civilians. Where a civilian directly participates in hostilities, he becomes a military threat that may be neutralized, including with lethal force. The same reasons why Gabriella Blum identifies threshold constraints against killing soldiers who pose no active threat apply with equal force in the direct participation context here. In short, civilians participating in network attacks might become the legitimate targets of states’ countermeasures, limited to technological means of neutralizing the threat posed by the computer system. Retaliatory denial of service attacks that would knock out the civilian’s access to network systems would satisfy military necessity considerations without reaching the absurd result that a civilian might be subject to a targeted killing for clicking a button on software.
## CONCLUSION
Threshold constraints matter to states, policymakers, military leaders, international norm entrepreneurs, and others. They find expression in a wide variety of customary and treaty-based IHL rules. Theories that privilege either a utilitarian or deontological rationale for IHL rules thus risk making serious category errors. # INTRODUCTION
States' attempts to regulate the battlefield behavior of their own and other states' belligerents are not new. Yet only in recent modernity have states focused on a set of *jus in bello* rules, allowing them to crystallize into a complex framework of inter-dependent textual and customary law. As currently understood, the rules of international humanitarian law (IHL), have two main problems.
One problem is theoretical. IHL rules forge a balance between deontological humanitarian concerns on one hand, and consequentialist military-advantage concerns on the other hand. Yet the literature provides inadequate theoretical foundations for the balances these rules make at a structural level. IHL theories can be described as fal-

ling into two parallel approaches. On one hand, the standard account holds that humanitarian law “impose[s] some limits, however ineffective, to a complete reversion to anarchy by the establishment of minimum standards on the conduct of war.” These scholars’ methodology, however, is ad hoc and unsatisfying. On the other hand, the rationalist or economic account posits that such laws—and state practice—are merely epiphenomenal of states’ interests; on this account the rules are “behavioral regularities rather than constraints on self-interested behavior.” The economic account provides methodological rigor but discounts the deontological constraints that inhere in formal doctrine and state practice.
The second problem is substantive. As I show below, IHL rules balance a variety of concerns, including moral constraints against killing noncombatants, attempts to minimize battlefield uncertainty, and states’ preferences for rules and tactics that reduce the costs of executing wars. In an age where technological advancements are rapidly changing the menu of tactical options from which states may choose in carrying out armed conflict, IHL rules will need to be reconsidered to determine whether they fit the emerging and operational opportunities and threats posed by cyberwarfare.
In this paper, I address each of these problems.
Regarding the first problem, I explain the standard and rationalist (economic) accounts of IHL rules, then explain how these accounts cannot alone account for the diversity of rules and principles observed in the formal doctrine and in state practice. I then seek a synthesis of the two strands of IHL scholarship, arguing that states’ revealed preference for norms fleshing out those “minimum standards” can not be brushed aside as mere “behavioral regularities.” To be sure, many of these minimum standards are the result of purely instrumental coordination, since all belligerents are better off with full compliance under conditions of transparency and effective enforcement. But recognizing that states sometimes act for non-instrumental reasons supplements rather than falsifies claims that states act rationally under other circumstances. By relying on psychological theories of moral cognition, which explain how people justify their decisions about whether to follow one or another mutually inconsistent behavioral prescriptions, it is possible to talk about instrumental and non-instrumental rationales in the same breath.

In the second half of the paper, I apply the constrained CBA approach to examine the emerging substantive problem of cyberwar. I shift focus from the theoretical to the substantive by showing how the concerns identified in the first part of the paper can and should influence institutional design considerations, especially under conditions of uncertainty about future battlefield situations. I aim to explore how states might seek to change those rules in light of anticipated (and even unknown) changes in battlefield technology.
## I. MODELING THE LAWS OF WAR
### A. Standard Account
Over centuries, social practices and wars have had constitutive effects on each other. The emergence of the modern nation-state—relatively recent in human history—was to some extent itself a measure to reduce the violence endemic to pre-social anarchy. States found untrammeled violence endemic in the anarchy of the battlefield, too, and micro-scale civilizing processes occurred there through the constitutive interplay of state practice and emerging norms of warfare.

Many of these rules admit no balancing test and permit no exception; they deal in absolutes. These intransgressible principles have the feel of deontological constraints against war's means. I say they have this "feel" because, as Eric Posner correctly notes, "it is hard to find a detailed defense" of these intransgressible principles on deontological grounds. The details of the defense appear piecemeal from a formalist reading of the doctrine and commentary, as well as from a functionalist reading of what states seek to accomplish in setting limits on the means of war. The position that military necessity permits means of effectively bringing about "the complete submission of the enemy" while minimizing the costs of war is not absolute; the set of possible means is limited by the requirement that such means be consistent with IHL. Indeed, Additional Protocol I to the Geneva Conventions exhorts that "the right of the Parties to [an international armed] conflict to choose methods or means of warfare is not unlimited." To that end, the few theorists who have addressed deontological ethics during wartime (like Michael Walzer) have emphasized the rights-centric nature of IHL rules, especially with regard to noncombatants. Even accepting that sometimes states will resort to war and that sometimes combatants will be killed (for this is their purpose), "no one else is made to be killed."
Given such constraints, it does not make much sense to describe or try to understand these rules solely in the language of consequentialism. They are not merely the solutions to cooperation games between adversarial states in which each state determines that on balance (and under conditions of transparency and full compliance) all are made better off by sparing noncombatants. ## II. UPDATING THE ECONOMIC MODEL
## A. Constrained Cost-Benefit Analysis
The standard and rationalist accounts of IHL rules have their respective virtues. On one hand, the standard account shows good fit with state practice and doctrine, recognizing that deontological and consequentialist considerations have exerted real influence in the institutional evolution and substantive content of IHL rules. On the other hand, compared to the standard account, rationalist accounts generally provide superior methodological rigor. Yet such accounts have paid surprisingly little attention to the structure and content of IHL rules, and their focus on reciprocity is underinclusive.
It is possible to bridge the gap between the rationalist and standard accounts, taking advantage of the methodological advantages of the former and the substantive accuracy of the latter. Eyal Zamir and Barak Medina have proposed a new technique for incorporating threshold conditions from deontological reasoning into consequentialist analysis. In the remainder of this paper, I employ their constrained CBA technique as a lens through which to analyze the interplay between humanitarian and pragmatic considerations in the design of IHL rules. States facing an international conflict have a menu of options to choose from. For our purposes the two important options are bargaining and going to war. Under the traditional rationalist explanations, states will choose war when the net gains expected from doing so outweigh the net gains expected from continued bargaining.59 Should a state choose war, it will expend resources—war capital—in the run-up and execution of war. In the usual case, expenditures will come from the state treasury and will be spread across the population; by preparing, maintaining, and deploying defensive and offensive capabilities, states provide classic public goods.60 These goods are often very bad, however: war is a wasteful and inefficient use of resources.61
When rational states choose to go to war, they will also choose strategies and tactics that reduce the costs of doing so. Expenditures on the war effort will include not just fixed costs of procuring, supplying, and maintaining durable military hardware, but also the costs of maintaining the military bureaucracy, recruiting and retaining soldiers, and purchasing consumable goods such as butter for the mess hall or bombs for the airplanes. Soldiers can also be understood as consumable goods—at least as a historical matter. Technological and other structural changes in warfare have not only made the soldier less fungible, but also reduced the military necessity for treating the soldier as wholly consumable.62
Cost reduction strategies may manifest on the front end—constraining states' ability to make expenditures for those goods—as a consequence of political pressure. This is especially likely to be true where the decision to go to war has non-neutral distributive consequence.

Parties to an armed conflict rarely experience technological parity with one another. Some armed conflicts occur because parties attempt to achieve technological parity. A state may learn that an adversary has developed new means of warfare that are more destructive or more efficient than previous means. In light of uncertainty about the adversary's intentions—whether purely defensive or also offensive—a rational state will seek to close the technological gap. This creates an unraveling or spiraling effect known as the security dilemma, in which both parties' attempts to close the gap make all worse off.76 To the extent that security dilemmas are a function of asymmetrical endowments of new technologies between potential adversaries, states may recognize that they will be jointly better off if they can ban or limit the use of such technologies.
These joint gains come in two types. First, there are classical gains to be had from limiting wasteful expenditure on arms races, as well as from reducing the risk of costs associated with damage—in particular, both direct military damage and collateral noncombatant damage. Second, there are gains to be had from reducing the uncertainty inherent to new technologies. As currently understood, the rules of international humanitarian law (IHL), have two main problems.
One problem is theoretical. IHL rules forge a balance between deontological humanitarian concerns on one hand, and consequentialist military-advantage concerns on the other hand. The “rules of the game” are sometimes absolute and nonderogable, as in the norms against torturing, summarily executing, or enslaving prisoners of war. According to the Nuremberg Tribunal’s judgment in the Hostage case, with regard to such rules “[m]ilitary necessity or expediency do not justify a violation.”³² Yet IHL plainly recognizes other circumstances in which military necessity is properly balanced against other interests. Consider how military necessity permits combatants to kill innocent noncombatants if proportionality threshold constraints are met.³³
Under the standard account, therefore, IHL rules are designed to serve not only humanitarian but also pragmatic interests. The perspective from which commentators and practitioners approach the problem of armed conflict is likely to manifest as a thumb on the scale in favor of one or the other interest.³⁴ Such differences in perspective are also likely to cause disagreements about the content of specific contentious rules. In light of such disagreements, it is remarkable that commentators and practitioners generally agree that international humanitarian law encompasses both humanitarian and pragmatic interests.³⁵

The rationalist turn in international law scholarship assumes states are egoistic unitary actors that maximize their self-interest.³⁷ Put simply, states are likely to violate international law where the costs of compliance outweigh the benefits. It is an open and closely contested question whether (or to what extent) rationalist accounts are better able to explain doctrine and state practice than other international-law perspectives (such as legal process, liberal, or constructivist theories). In this paper I accept the methodological framework of rationalist approaches in attempting a synthesis between economic and standard accounts of IHL. But accepting that states sometimes act consistent with rationalist predictions (following the logic of consequences) is not to deny that states sometimes act inconsistent with those predictions (following the logic of appropriateness). Even if rationalist explanations are sometimes underinclusive, other times the explanations are robust and show good fit with state practice.
Rationality assumptions undercut whatever force moral concerns may have, for rules are designed as instrumental means of serving states' strategic, material, and other interests. In other words, scholars within the rationalist tradition define the goals in terms of the interests that given rules serve, and costs and benefits that accrue from compliance with those rules. ## II. UPDATING THE ECONOMIC MODEL
## A. Constrained Cost-Benefit Analysis
The standard and rationalist accounts of IHL rules have their respective virtues. On one hand, the standard account shows good fit with state practice and doctrine, recognizing that deontological and consequentialist considerations have exerted real influence in the institutional evolution and substantive content of IHL rules. On the other hand, compared to the standard account, rationalist accounts generally provide superior methodological rigor. Yet such accounts have paid surprisingly little attention to the structure and content of IHL rules, and their focus on reciprocity is underinclusive.
It is possible to bridge the gap between the rationalist and standard accounts, taking advantage of the methodological advantages of the former and the substantive accuracy of the latter. Eyal Zamir and Barak Medina have proposed a new technique for incorporating threshold conditions from deontological reasoning into consequentialist analysis.⁴⁹ In the remainder of this paper, I employ their constrained CBA technique as a lens through which to analyze the interplay between humanitarian and pragmatic considerations in the design of IHL rules. In this draft I only briefly explain their approach before turning to a discussion of substantive IHL rules and the rules' implications under conditions of technological change and the emergence of cyberwarfare. I do so for space reasons, and in so doing I assume the reader at this preliminary stage is familiar with Zamir and Medina's thesis.

Under the traditional rationalist explanations, states will choose war when the net gains expected from doing so outweigh the net gains expected from continued bargaining.59 Should a state choose war, it will expend resources—war capital—in the run-up and execution of war. # A. Technology in the Laws of War
Parties to an armed conflict rarely experience technological parity with one another. Some armed conflicts occur because parties attempt to achieve technological parity. A state may learn that an adversary has developed new means of warfare that are more destructive or more efficient than previous means. In light of uncertainty about the adversary's intentions—whether purely defensive or also offensive—a rational state will seek to close the technological gap. This creates an unraveling or spiraling effect known as the security dilemma, in which both parties' attempts to close the gap make all worse off.76 To the extent that security dilemmas are a function of asymmetrical endowments of new technologies between potential adversaries, states may recognize that they will be jointly better off if they can ban or limit the use of such technologies.
These joint gains come in two types. First, there are classical gains to be had from limiting wasteful expenditure on arms races, as well as from reducing the risk of costs associated with damage—in particular, both direct military damage and collateral noncombatant damage. Second, there are gains to be had from reducing the uncertainty inherent to new technologies. This uncertainty includes not only the amount of suffering inflicted on combatants relative to the military advantage gained, but also the magnitude or even threshold presence of damage inflicted on noncombatants and noncombatant objects. Recall from earlier that uncertainty increases the risk that threshold constraints may be violated. All else equal, norm entrepreneurs are likely to advocate for, and states are likely to adopt, rules that reduce the risk of inadvertently violating a threshold constraint.
Such concerns have driven states to adopt these rules. In practice, however, they have had limited success in doing so. Yet only in recent modernity have states focused on a set of *jus in bello* rules, allowing them to crystallize into a complex framework of inter-dependent textual and customary law. As currently understood, the rules of international humanitarian law (IHL), have two main problems.
One problem is theoretical. IHL rules forge a balance between deontological humanitarian concerns on one hand, and consequentialist military-advantage concerns on the other hand. On one hand, the standard account holds that humanitarian law “impose[s] some limits, however ineffective, to a complete reversion to anarchy by the establishment of minimum standards on the conduct of war.”¹ These scholars’ methodology, however, is ad hoc and unsatisfying. On the other hand, the rationalist or economic account posits that such laws—and state practice—are merely epiphenomenal of states’ interests; on this account the rules are “behavioral regularities rather than constraints on self-interested behavior.”² The economic account provides methodological rigor but discounts the deontological constraints that inhere in formal doctrine and state practice.
The second problem is substantive. As I show below, IHL rules balance a variety of concerns, including moral constraints against killing noncombatants, attempts to minimize battlefield uncertainty, and states’ preferences for rules and tactics that reduce the costs of executing wars. In an age where technological advancements are rapidly changing the menu of tactical options from which states may choose in carrying out armed conflict, IHL rules will need to be reconsidered to determine whether they fit the emerging and operational opportunities and threats posed by cyberwarfare.
In this paper, I address each of these problems.
Regarding the first problem, I explain the standard and rationalist (economic) accounts of IHL rules, then explain how these accounts cannot alone account for the diversity of rules and principles observed in the formal doctrine and in state practice. I then seek a synthesis of the two strands of IHL scholarship, arguing that states’ revealed preference for norms fleshing out those “minimum standards” can not be brushed aside as mere “behavioral regularities.” To be sure, many of these minimum standards are the result of purely instrumental coordination, since all belligerents are better off with full compliance under conditions of transparency and effective enforcement. But recognizing that states sometimes act for non-instrumental reasons supplements rather than falsifies claims that states act rationally under other circumstances. The rationalist turn in international law scholarship assumes states are egoistic unitary actors that maximize their self-interest.³⁷ Put simply, states are likely to violate international law where the costs of compliance outweigh the benefits. It is an open and closely contested question whether (or to what extent) rationalist accounts are better able to explain doctrine and state practice than other international-law perspectives (such as legal process, liberal, or constructivist theories). In this paper I accept the methodological framework of rationalist approaches in attempting a synthesis between economic and standard accounts of IHL. But accepting that states sometimes act consistent with rationalist predictions (following the logic of consequences) is not to deny that states sometimes act inconsistent with those predictions (following the logic of appropriateness). Even if rationalist explanations are sometimes underinclusive, other times the explanations are robust and show good fit with state practice.

## II. UPDATING THE ECONOMIC MODEL
## A. Constrained Cost-Benefit Analysis
The standard and rationalist accounts of IHL rules have their respective virtues. On one hand, the standard account shows good fit with state practice and doctrine, recognizing that deontological and consequentialist considerations have exerted real influence in the institutional evolution and substantive content of IHL rules. On the other hand, compared to the standard account, rationalist accounts generally provide superior methodological rigor. Yet such accounts have paid surprisingly little attention to the structure and content of IHL rules, and their focus on reciprocity is underinclusive.
It is possible to bridge the gap between the rationalist and standard accounts, taking advantage of the methodological advantages of the former and the substantive accuracy of the latter. Under the traditional rationalist explanations, states will choose war when the net gains expected from doing so outweigh the net gains expected from continued bargaining.59 Should a state choose war, it will expend resources—war capital—in the run-up and execution of war. In the usual case, expenditures will come from the state treasury and will be spread across the population; by preparing, maintaining, and deploying defensive and offensive capabilities, states provide classic public goods.60 These goods are often very bad, however: war is a wasteful and inefficient use of resources.61 When rational states choose to go to war, they will also choose strategies and tactics that reduce the costs of doing so. Expenditures on the war effort will include not just fixed costs of procuring, supplying, and maintaining durable military hardware, but also the costs of maintaining the military bureaucracy, recruiting and retaining soldiers, and purchasing consumable goods such as butter for the mess hall or bombs for the airplanes. Technological and other structural changes in warfare have not only made the soldier less fungible, but also reduced the military necessity for treating the soldier as wholly consumable.62 Cost reduction strategies may manifest on the front end—constraining states' ability to make expenditures for those goods—as a consequence of political pressure. Uncertainty increases the risk of harm to noncombatants, and efforts to reduce uncertainty shifts some quantum of this risk away from noncombatants to combatants.⁶⁸ States will thus prefer strong, clear rules where uncertainty about the military advantage to be gained from given conduct is very low or approaching zero. These rules are absolute and exceptional, respectively, based on the magnitude and direction of the military advantage. When the military advantage is very low and very certain, the consequences will be insufficient to trigger the deontological threshold. The result will be an absolute rule, a prediction seen in practice (as in the norm against killing civilians when there is no discernable military advantage). By contrast, when the military advantage is very high and very certain, the consequences will be so overwhelming that they will be easily sufficient to trigger the deontological threshold. State practice in equilibrium is likely to reflect states' beliefs that deontological thresholds are serious (for otherwise state practice would show constant defection), but not absolute. The result in these cases will likely be a necessity-exception rule, tracking Blum's proposal for a limited category of humanitarian necessity.⁶⁹ Third, and closely related, states will prefer tactics that maximize the military advantage expected to accrue from the marginal expenditure of war capital. Unfortunately for states—candidly, for everyone involved—battlefield uncertainty and the fog of war increase the risky tail of that expected military advantage. States can expend capital for war and other uses. In Posner’s view, destructive weapons have beneficial deterrence effects but harmful effects on “productive capital, defined broadly to include the human capital of civilians and of soldiers after they are demobilized.”75 Such effects are surely costly. But to the extent that destructive weapons increase the likelihood that those who pose no threat—such as non-combatants, or combatants rendered hors de combat—will be killed, they are also that much more likely to violate threshold constraints against killing such persons.
## III. THE SPECIAL CASE OF CYBERWARFARE The constrained CBA account set out in the previous Part can help explain a wide range of treaty and customary IHL rules. Uncertainty, risk-shifting, threshold-constraint concerns, and cost-reduction preferences play important roles in shaping IHL rules, which in turn constrain and channel the tactical options states can select in carrying out armed conflict. In this part I shift focus by showing how these same concerns exert institutional-design effects when we are uncertain about what future battlefield situations will look like. I shift from explaining and understanding IHL rules as they currently exist, to explaining and understanding how states might seek to change those rules in light of anticipated (and even unknown) changes in battlefield technology.

Some armed conflicts occur because parties attempt to achieve technological parity. A state may learn that an adversary has developed new means of warfare that are more destructive or more efficient than previous means. In light of uncertainty about the adversary's intentions—whether purely defensive or also offensive—a rational state will seek to close the technological gap. This creates an unraveling or spiraling effect known as the security dilemma, in which both parties' attempts to close the gap make all worse off.76 To the extent that security dilemmas are a function of asymmetrical endowments of new technologies between potential adversaries, states may recognize that they will be jointly better off if they can ban or limit the use of such technologies.
These joint gains come in two types. First, there are classical gains to be had from limiting wasteful expenditure on arms races, as well as from reducing the risk of costs associated with damage—in particular, both direct military damage and collateral noncombatant damage. Second, there are gains to be had from reducing the uncertainty inherent to new technologies. This uncertainty includes not only the amount of suffering inflicted on combatants relative to the military advantage gained, but also the magnitude or even threshold presence of damage inflicted on noncombatants and noncombatant objects. Recall from earlier that uncertainty increases the risk that threshold constraints may be violated. All else equal, norm entrepreneurs are likely to advocate for, and states are likely to adopt, rules that reduce the risk of inadvertently violating a threshold constraint.
Such concerns have driven states to adopt these rules. In practice, however, they have had limited success in doing so. For example, before World War I, states unsuccessfully tried to place outright bans on aerial bombardment of undefended towns, then sought to"regulat[e] the military potential by restricting [bombardment's] use under the law of armed conflict."77 Such limits will be difficult to achieve if they Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=1762342 Tierney [2011 affect states differently on account of technological asymmetries—arms gaps—at the time the treaty or custom is being developed.⁷⁸ As the world becomes increasingly networked in an absolute sense, relative technological asymmetries are likely to continue to grow, especially between more and less developed states. Such asymmetries mean that states are unlikely to converge on rules that limit the use of computer network attacks (CNAs)—an anticipated and emerging revolution in military means that commentators have unfortunately dubbed cyberwar.⁷⁹ Perhaps this is a good thing, for as commentators like Richard Clarke have warned, attempts to ban cyberwar are likely to tie the United States’ strategic hands in unsatisfying ways.⁸⁰ A century after states failed in banning and regulating aerial bombardment, problems of technological development and technological asymmetries will continue to puzzle policymakers, military officials, and lawyers. If the cyberwar threat is real and not overblown—a condition that is not necessarily satisfied—states will have to develop IHL rules that can account for the new means of networked warfare, and the uncertainty these means bring with regard to collateral consequences for noncombatants.

They sharply reduce transaction costs in the public (business and government) as well as private spheres by allowing near-instantaneous transmission of information across thousands of miles. Interconnectedness is a virtue, but it is also a vice. If users are unsophisticated, they may open themselves to exploitation or to data or identity theft—without even knowing it. They find expression in a wide variety of customary and treaty-based IHL rules. Theories that privilege either a utilitarian or deontological rationale for IHL rules thus risk making serious category errors.
